Issues.Title: TypeScript peer dependency warnings
Issues.Body:
```
npm WARN @angular/compiler-cli@8.2.5 requires a peer of typescript@>=3.4 <3.6 but none is installed. You must install peer dependencies yourself.
npm WARN @angular/core@8.2.5 requires a peer of zone.js@~0.9.1 but none is installed. You must install peer dependencies yourself.
```

And typescript 3.6.3 just came out now. Why the lag in having angular handle 3.6.x? Is there some kind of blocker?
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "TypeScript peer dependency warnings" (#32600)

Issues.Title: feat(common): make `HttpParameterCodec` injectable
Issues.Body:
You can inject custom `HttpParameterCodec` to not use default parameter encoder.

## PR Checklist
Please check if your PR fulfills the following requirements:

- [x] The commit message follows our guidelines: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#commit
- [x] Tests for the changes have been added (for bug fixes / features)
- [x] Docs have been added / updated (for bug fixes / features)


## PR Type
What kind of change does this PR introduce?

<!-- Please check the one that applies to this PR using "x". -->
```
[ ] Bugfix
[x] Feature
[ ] Code style update (formatting, local variables)
[ ] Refactoring (no functional changes, no api changes)
[ ] Build related changes
[ ] CI related changes
[ ] Documentation content changes
[ ] angular.io application / infrastructure changes
[ ] Other... Please describe:
```

## What is the current behavior?

Specific API server can't accept character. '+' so we need to encode that.

https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/5298b2bda34a8766b28c8425e447f94598b23901/packages/common/http/src/params.ts#L64

But angular's standard encoder decode that.

So developer needs to add custom encoder every http method invokes. and it's very annoying.

Related Issue Numbers: #19710, #23157 #18261, #18719, #11058

## What is the new behavior?

User can provide default custom http parameter codec.

## Does this PR introduce a breaking change?
```
[ ] Yes
[x] No
```


## Other information
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "feat(common): make `HttpParameterCodec` injectable" (#32598)

Issues.Title: refactor(ivy): get rid of styling cleanup functions outside of styling code
Issues.Body:
Prior to this patch, each time `advance()` would run (or when a
templateFn or hostBindings code exits) then the core change detection
code would check to see whether the styling data needs to be reset. This
patch removes that functionality and places everything inside of the
scheduled styling exit function. This means that each time one or more
styling bindings run (even if the value hasn't changed) then an exit
function will be scheduled and that will do all the cleanup.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "refactor(ivy): get rid of styling cleanup functions outside of styling code" (#32591)

Issues.Body:

source file wouldn't have to be created if there were no diagnostics.

`ts.SourceFile` for file when diagnostics are queried. This removal is
just to make the function a minimal amount simpler.

Issues.Title: feat(language-service): provide diagnostic for invalid templateUrls
Issues.Body:
`templateUrls` that do not point to actual files are now diagnosed as such
by the Language Service. Support for `styleUrls` will come in a next PR.

This introduces a utility method `getPropertyValueOfType` that scans
TypeScript ASTs until a property assignment whose initializer of a
certain type is found. This PR also notices a couple of things that
could be improved in the language-service implementation, such as
enumerating directive properties and unifying common logic, that will be
fixed in future PRs.

Part of #32564.

Issues.Title: feat(common): allow default currency code to be configurable
Issues.Body:
Default currency code in CurrencyPipe is currently hardcoded to USD
and is not configurable. This commit allows the default currency code
to be configurable by adding a CURRENCY_CODE injection token.

Example:
```
providers: [{ provide: CURRENCY_CODE, useValue: "GBP" }]
...
{{ 123.45 | currency }} // outputs ¬£123.45 as opposed to always $123.45 before
```

Issues.Title: Angular compiler not fetch template error
Issues.Body:
Hello,

We have the following component: 

```
@Component({
  changeDetection: ChangeDetectionStrategy.OnPush,
  selector: 'component-a,
  template `Hello from component A`,
})
export class ComponentA {
 @Output() change = new EventEmitter<{}>();
}

```
**In Parent component B we are injecting component A**

```
@Component({
  changeDetection: ChangeDetectionStrategy.OnPush,
  selector: 'component-b,
  template `
<component-a>
(change)="change('A', 'B')"
</component-a>

`,
})
export class ComponentB {
 // **Notice that change accept 3 arguments while 2 are passed above only.**
 change(A, B, C) {
   console.log(A,B,C);
 }
}
```



What is happening? In WebStorm tslint detect error "Invalid number of arguments 3 expected" while during compilation and building application no errors. 

Do we have something misconfigured? 

Here is package.json:

```
"dependencies": {
    "@angular/animations": "^8.0.3",
    "@angular/common": "^8.0.3",
    "@angular/core": "^8.0.3",

Issues.Title: Add autocorrect attribute support on <input> field for iOS devices
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ feature request

### Description
The `autocorrect` attribute on `<input>` fields causes Angular to throw an error.
Indeed, this attribute is not part of the HTML5 specification and is therefore nonstandard.
However, this attribute allows for disabling predictive typing on iOS devices, which happens to be really useful.


### Describe the solution you'd like
Add support for the `autocorrect` attribute for iOS devices.
Allowed values are `on` and `off`


### Describe alternatives you've considered
At the moment, the only working solution (to do it properly) is to go through `Renderer2`, and dynamically set the attribute whenever it is needed.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Add autocorrect attribute support on <input> field for iOS devices" (#32575)

Issues.Title: Angular Router ExtraOptions initialNavigation does not default to enabled
Issues.Body:
<!--üîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖ

Oh hi there! üòÑ

To expedite issue processing please search open and closed issues before submitting a new one.
Existing issues often contain information about workarounds, resolution, or progress updates.

üîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖ-->

# üìö Docs or angular.io bug report

At https://angular.io/api/router/ExtraOptions, the docs state that `initialNavigation` defaults to `enabled`:

> One of enabled (the default) or disabled.

This is not the case. Looking at the code (https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/master/packages/router/src/router_module.ts#L556),  it defaults to `legacy_enabled`, which is not the same as `enabled` (e.g. `enabled` is required for SSR to work as per https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/15716#issuecomment-291025332).

The docs do not mention the legacy values as these are deprecated, so I'm not sure what would be the best way to phrase it. Maybe:

> One of enabled or disabled (defaults to a legacy behavior for compatibility).
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Angular Router ExtraOptions initialNavigation does not default to enabled" (#32571)

Issues.Body:
Script bundles were not being subject to the terser mangle optimizations when using bundle down leveling.
This change also allows terser to perform ECMA 6 level compress and output optimizations on the actual application bundles (non-script bundles) which can provide for further size improvements.  Also limits the parsing for optimizations of the script bundles to one step.

Fixes #15489
Supersedes #15507

Issues.Title: Registering lazy routes (dynamic import) at runtime
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ Feature request


### Command (mark with an `x`)
```
- [ ] new
- [x] build
- [x] serve
- [ ] test
- [ ] e2e
- [ ] generate
- [ ] add
- [ ] update
- [ ] lint
- [ ] xi18n
- [ ] run
- [ ] config
- [ ] help
- [ ] version
- [ ] doc
```

### Description
With the [string loadChildren syntax deprecated](https://angular.io/api/router/DeprecatedLoadChildren) in Angular 8, in favor of the [dynamic import syntax](https://angular.io/api/router/LoadChildrenCallback), it seems it will no longer be possible to register lazy routes at runtime.

Please note that by adding lazy routes at runtime, I'm not referring to loading modules completely unknown to Webpack. These modules would be part of libs that are compiled together with the application, so the chunks would be known to Webpack, but routes would only be added to the router config as a result of a Web API call.

### Describe the solution you'd like
Basically, I'd like to be able to do the following (from a component or e.g. a ngrx effect), and successfully navigate to the new route and its children, while using JIT, AOT and with Ivy (AOT):

```javascript
this._router.config.unshift({
  path: 'dynamic',
  loadChildren: () => import(modulePathReceivedFromServer).then(m => m[moduleNameReceivedFromServer])
});
this._router.resetConfig(this._router.config);
```

With dynamic imports working this way, one could also easily load lazy modules on demand/without routing to them (currently possible with the [deprecated SystemJsNgModuleLoader](https://angular.io/api/core/SystemJsNgModuleLoader)).

### Describe alternatives you've considered
The only alternative I can think of is a Webpack plugin doing something similar to what the `AngularCompilerPlugin` does in `contextModuleFactory.afterResolve`.
You can see my detailed analysis, with a simple demo app and the solutions I could think of here: https://github.com/mbinic/dynamic-lazy-routes#dynamic-lazy-routes-experiment. The last few commits show the code using JIT, AOT and Ivy (AOT), route adding code being almost identical for all cases.

Constructive criticism from the experts is the best way to learn, so I'd love to get your input even if you think this is a bad idea or just plain nonsense. And I'd gladly make a PR if this is something you'd support, to angular-cli and webpack :)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Registering lazy routes (dynamic import) at runtime" (#15556)

Issues.Title: ci: update saucelabs protractor config to run e2e tests in series rather than parallel
Issues.Body:
Our combined CI usage is often hitting the max number of concurrent sessions on saucelabs.  Currentl the saucelabs job takes 12 sessions at once because the tests run in parallel, instead we should run these in series to only use 1 session.  

It should not have a large impact on overall CI run time as each of the tests take ~10 seconds so we are moving from the Saucelabs steps taking ~1:45 to ~3:00 each.  Based on previous CI runs it looks like this change will still cause the saucelabs test runs to complete ~15 minutes before other jobs in the sequence.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "ci: update saucelabs protractor config to run e2e tests in series rather than parallel" (#15545)

Issues.Title: support option passthrough (additionalProperties) in schematics and builders
Issues.Body:
<!--üîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖ

Oh hi there! üòÑ

To expedite issue processing please search open and closed issues before submitting a new one.
Existing issues often contain information about workarounds, resolution, or progress updates.

üîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖ-->


# üöÄ Feature request


### Command (mark with an `x`)
<!-- Can you pin-point the command or commands that are relevant for this feature request? -->
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏èedit: -->
```
- [ ] new
- [ ] build
- [ ] serve
- [ ] test
- [ ] e2e
- [x] generate
- [ ] add
- [ ] update
- [ ] lint
- [ ] xi18n
- [x] run
- [ ] config
- [ ] help
- [ ] version
- [ ] doc
```

### Description
I want to create schematics and builders that support options not explicitly defined in the schema.  

For example, I want to create a builder that spawns a command just passing through the options from the cli. Pretty much like the [example](https://angular.io/guide/cli-builder#schedule-and-run) in angular.io website although instead of defining `command` and `args` options I'd like the user to type (or define in a target) the options as she or he were executing the command directly. 

### Describe the solution you'd like
According to json-schema's draft, [it is possible](https://json-schema.org/understanding-json-schema/reference/object.html#pattern-properties) to combine `properties`, `propertiesPatterns` and `additionalProperties` to define a schema that allows any property and even control the allowed types.

Currently, the cli only considers `boolean` as the possible type of the property `additionalProperties`. 

https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/blob/fe8666073b4f357d4614bf90ac39225980ebe24c/packages/angular/cli/models/architect-command.ts#L244

I'd suggest to make changes in https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/blob/fe8666073b4f357d4614bf90ac39225980ebe24c/packages/angular/cli/utilities/json-schema.ts#L136 to consider an object as possible value of the property `additionalProperties` and parse the options not included in the `properties` object using its value as definition. 

So, if I create a builder with a schema as follows:

```
 {
  "$schema": "http://json-schema.org/schema",
  "title": "My builder",
  "description": "Executes a command",
  "type": "object",
  "additionalProperties": {
    "type": "string"
  },
  "properties": {
    "command": {
      "type": "string",
      "description": "Command to be executed"
    }
  },
  "required": [
    "command"
  ],
  "definitions": {
  }
}
```

And I pass the following options to the method `parseJsonSchemaToOptions`:

```
['--command', 'my-script', '--foo', 'bar']
```

The method returns the following array:

```
[
 {
   "name": "command",
   "type": "string",
   "required": true,
   "hidden": false
 }
]
``` 

Ignoring the option `--foo`. 

In my option when additionalProperties is an object it should use its value to define the rest of properties returning the following array:

```
[
 {
   "name": "command",
   "type": "string",
   "required": true,
   "hidden": false
 },
 {
   "name": "foo",
   "type": "string",
   "required": false,
   "hidden": false
]
``` 

### Describe alternatives you've considered
If the property `additionalProperties` is set `true` the options not defined explicitly are "stashed" in a property with the name "--" and therefore builders can access to them. 

However, this is not an intuitive workaround and requires the developers to parse these options (split them when using `=` or pair them when using them separately).
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "support option passthrough (additionalProperties) in schematics and builders" (#15565)

This PR contains the following updates:

### Release Notes

<details>
<summary>fabiosantoscode/terser</summary>

### [`v4.3.1`](https://togithub.com/fabiosantoscode/terser/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md#v431)

[Compare Source](https://togithub.com/fabiosantoscode/terser/compare/v4.3.0...v4.3.1)

-   Fixed an issue from 4.3.0 where any block scope within a for loop erroneously had its parent set to the function scopee
-   Fixed an issue where compressing IIFEs with argument expansions would result in some parameters becoming undefined
-   addEventListener options argument's properties are now part of the DOM properties list.

### [`v4.3.0`](https://togithub.com/fabiosantoscode/terser/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md#v430)

[Compare Source](https://togithub.com/fabiosantoscode/terser/compare/v4.2.1...v4.3.0)

-   Do not drop computed object keys with side effects
-   Functions passed to other functions in calls are now wrapped in parentheses by default, which speeds up loading most modules
-   Objects with computed properties are now less likely to be hoisted
-   Speed and memory efficiency optimizations
-   Fixed scoping issues with `try` and `switch`

</details>

Issues.Title: Enable extension of #/definitions/project & #/definitions/target
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ Feature request
### Command (mark with an `x`)
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏èedit: -->
```
...
- [x] run
...
```

### Description
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏è--> Hi folks,
first of all, great Job with the whole CLI & Architect project. A lot of great capabitilies :raised_hands:. 
Some background:
Since three weeks I'm working currently on something to enable the [micro frontends](https://martinfowler.com/articles/micro-frontends.html) approach with angular. 
The first two weeks I spent with evaluating in how this is even possible together with angular:
 _Besides @angular/elements, I have the feeling that web components were never really the focus for the angular team, right?...._
 _**But!!!**..... it works. There are some pitfalls and little details, but all in all, I do have a solution so far, where I'm peacefully happy with to use on a larger environment in enterprise._ 
Some of the things I managed to solve:
- **Share the @angular libraries** between the angular-elements instead of bundling and loading them for each one again.
- **Make use of Ivy for compilation**. This works both for the shared vendor.bundle and for the angular
- **Provide tooling for all of this** (builders, schematics etc.) <-- Spent the third week with

(Yes, I am the one with [2kb angular element](https://twitter.com/simsek_dev/status/1168163228574277639), I'm willing to provide access to the private repo if needed. But I'm not going to make it public right now) 

#### My issue comes with the last point:
On one side, **you provide** great CLI API's for extensions and custom logic, 
but on the other side, **you restrict** people which I don't really get why. 
What I'm talking about is the [json schema for the angular workspace](https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/blob/master/packages/angular/cli/lib/config/schema.json). 
As long as we tinker with builders, everything is okay. But once you need little more than this, things get complicated:
- [This](https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/blob/master/packages/angular/cli/lib/config/schema.json#L396) prevents us from extending the project schema definition
- [This](https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/blob/master/packages/angular/cli/lib/config/schema.json#L398) small WTF
- [This](https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/blob/master/packages/angular/cli/lib/config/schema.json#L402) prevents us to define a custom targets schema

> ### Why though?

**Let's assume** you have one project composited of mutliple subprojects. 
All of the **sub-projects share** some same information, because 
even though they **can be independent** from each other, 
**they do** have some kind of **relation** 
when it comes to that **bigger composition project**.

### Describe the solution you'd like
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏è--> 
Just allow additionalProperties? In which way they disturb? :thinking:
A builder may just use those properties he is interested in and ignore all the others.

### Describe alternatives you've considered
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏è--> 
So far, that I'm started to code an own angular workspace parser with utilities, because **builder** are allowed to have additionalProperties (WTF!!!). 
And thats the gap I'm using currently to provide some shared information between my angular elements and the container project.

I started to think about using a completely separate custom json for my configuration, which would be sad just because of some flags I'm not getting why they are set.

Kind regards
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Enable extension of #/definitions/project & #/definitions/target" (#15547)

Issues.Title: Autocomplete closes when scrolling on a touch device
Issues.Body:
Steps to reproduce:
1. Open https://material.angular.io/components/autocomplete/overview in any touch device
2. Use the example on the page, tap to show autocomplete
3. If it was a longer list or you're viewing on a small device you would want to scroll to see the rest of the list. Scroll with touch.
4. On touchend the autocomplete closes
 
 
#### Expected Behavior

It is the intended behavior according to the code in autcomplete.es5.js L:601
```
return merge(fromEvent(this._document, 'click'), fromEvent(this._document, 'touchend'))`
    .pipe(filter(function (event) {
            /** @type {?} */
            var clickTarget = (/** @type {?} */ (event.target));
            /** @type {?} */
            var formField = _this._formField ?
                _this._formField._elementRef.nativeElement : null;
            return _this._overlayAttached &&
                clickTarget !== _this._element.nativeElement &&
                (!formField || !formField.contains(clickTarget)) &&
                (!!_this._overlayRef && !_this._overlayRef.overlayElement.contains(clickTarget));
        }));
```

The menu closes on touchend but I think it's a bug because it's normal to expect users to scroll on a mobile device to see the rest of the list. I think the `fromEvent(this._document, 'touchend')` should be removed or the code changed to allow scrolling

#### Environment

- Angular: 7.2.13
- CDK/Material: 7.3.7
- Browser(s): All browsers on a touch device
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): All operating systems that support touch
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Autocomplete closes when scrolling on a touch device" (#17039)

Issues.Title: Add scope attribute to headers in DatePicker for improved accessibility
Issues.Body:
#### Feature Description

The current `<th>`' fields with the days of the week for the material date picker do not have a `scope` attribute. The [scope attribute](https://webaim.org/techniques/tables/data#headers) provides screen readers additional context about which table header is a row or column header. 

Adding `scope='column` for each `<th>` containing a day of the week would improve accessibility for the date picker for those using screen readers.

Current table header code for matDatepicker:

```html
<thead class="mat-calendar-table-header">
<tr>
  <th aria-label="Sunday" class="ng-star-inserted">S</th>
  <th aria-label="Monday" class="ng-star-inserted">M</th>
  <th aria-label="Tuesday" class="ng-star-inserted">T</th>
  <th aria-label="Wednesday" class="ng-star-inserted">W</th>
  <th aria-label="Thursday" class="ng-star-inserted">T</th>
  <th aria-label="Friday" class="ng-star-inserted">F</th>
  <th aria-label="Saturday" class="ng-star-inserted">S</th>
</tr>
</thead>
```

Proposed fix for this code:

```html
<thead class="mat-calendar-table-header">
<tr>
  <th aria-label="Sunday" scope="col" class="ng-star-inserted">S</th>
  <th aria-label="Monday" scope="col" class="ng-star-inserted">M</th>
  <th aria-label="Tuesday" scope="col" class="ng-star-inserted">T</th>
  <th aria-label="Wednesday" scope="col" class="ng-star-inserted">W</th>
  <th aria-label="Thursday" scope="col" class="ng-star-inserted">T</th>
  <th aria-label="Friday" scope="col" class="ng-star-inserted">F</th>
  <th aria-label="Saturday" scope="col" class="ng-star-inserted">S</th>
</tr>
</thead>
```

#### Use Case

All users who interact with matDatepicker via a screen reader would benefit from this change, as the relationship between the day headers and the columns would be made explicit and clear for screen reading tools.

See also https://github.com/angular/components/issues/16317 for other proposed accessibility fixes for this input.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Add scope attribute to headers in DatePicker for improved accessibility" (#17038)

Issues.Title: Mat Tab does not work with web components
Issues.Body:
When web components are used in a tab, on switching a tab material removes them from DOM instead of hiding them. 

When web components are removed from DOM, they get destroyed and **lose their state.**
Consequently, switching back to same tab makes them re render again from scratch.

Issues.Title: build: run custom tslint rules on new packages
Issues.Body:
Apparently we didn't run the custom tslint rules for the new packages
that have been merged (`youtube-player` and `google-maps`). This is
because we have a whitelist of packages we want to run these custom
lint rules against.

It should be actually the other way around where we only specify the folders
we _don't_ want to lint against. That way, new folders are automatically linted
and we need to explicitly exclude them if we don't want to run for those.

**Note**: Marked as target minor because it will not merge safely into the patch branch (as youtube-player is not part of that branch).

I'm not sure if the `module.id` is technically needed for those packages (not sure if they are synced into g3), but we should add them for now to satisfy the `validate-decorators` lint rule. We can remove them as part of the overall cleanup with #13883
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "build: run custom tslint rules on new packages" (#17033)

Issues.Title: Multiple overlay containers
Issues.Body:
#### What are you trying to do?

I'd like to render certain overlays in a custom container, whereas other overlays should be rendered in the 'default' overlay container.

#### What troubleshooting steps have you tried?

I've implemented a custom `OverlayContainer` that is provided in the module which also imports the `OverlayModule` to open overlays from a service. This works, all overlays in that module are positioned within the custom overlay container. However, all *other* overlays (such as `mat-select`, `mat-dialog` are also opened in the custom overlay container. I've tried to override the overlay container in the parent module, but then all overlays are positioned within that container. 

Interestingly, snackbars are positioned correctly in the global overlay container, so I think it is possible to have multiple overlay containers, but I just can't find out how to accomplish this.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Multiple overlay containers" (#17024)

Issues.Title: fix: annotate a couple base classes with @Directive for Ivy
Issues.Body:
There are two base classes in Material/CDK which are intended to be extended
by user code: BasePortalHost and MatFormFieldControl.

This commit annotates them with `@Directive`. The best way to do this is to
use `@Directive()` but this is not supported by Angular 8.x, on which
Material and the CDK still depend. Therefore, a workaround is used with a
selector which will never be matched. Modules are also added to satisfy the
View Engine compiler.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix: annotate a couple base classes with @Directive for Ivy" (#17022)

Issues.Title: CDK BreapointObserver emits multiple 'true' for differents sizes of screen
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction
Steps to reproduce:
1. Write this code in a service, then subscribe. See in console.
```
isLandscape$: Observable<boolean> = this.breakpointObserver.observe(['(orientation: portrait)', '(orientation: landscape)']).pipe(
    map((result: BreakpointState) => {
      console.log('result', result);
      return result.matches;
    })
  );
screenSizes$: Observable<boolean> = this.breakpointObserver
    .observe([Breakpoints.XSmall, Breakpoints.Small, Breakpoints.Medium, Breakpoints.Large, Breakpoints.XLarge])
    .pipe(
      map((result: BreakpointState) => {
        console.log('result', result);
        return result.matches;
      })
    );
 ```
 
#### Expected Behavior

What behavior were you expecting to see?

I'm expecting to get only 1 condition set to true for media queries defined in the CDK.

#### Actual Behavior

What behavior did you actually see?

My browser is 1903px wide. The 1st time i load the page, I see in the console the Large and XLarge conditions set to true: 

```
(min-width: 1280px) and (max-width: 1919.99px): true
(min-width: 1920px): true
```
Then, when I resize my window, this time, the CDK emits only `(min-width: 1280px) and (max-width: 1919.99px): true`.

The same type of error occurs screen when I first get to 'xs' screen by resizing the window: 2 conditions set to true (for Small & XSmall screen sizes):

```
(max-width: 599.99px): true
(min-width: 600px) and (max-width: 959.99px): true
```
Then, when I resize again my window, i only get `(max-width: 599.99px): true`.

ALSO:

When i reload the page in 'xs' size, I get the right values set for both isLandscape & Screen size.
But when i resize the page, I get:
```
breakpoints: {
(orientation: landscape): false
(orientation: portrait): false
}
matches: false
```
I also get a no match from times to times for the screen sizes...

So, that's just not possible.
- The CDK should be able to emit that I'm still in portrait mode, 
- the CDK should be able to detect my screen size any time.

#### Environment

- Angular: 8.0.0
- CDK/Material: 8.0.0
- Browser(s): Chrome 76
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu):  Windows 10
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "CDK BreapointObserver emits multiple 'true' for differents sizes of screen" (#17013)
